Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: I have not only increased knowledge of the science, policy, and management practices around water in the US and internationally, but also improved my systems thinking. This course engaged interdisciplinary thinking and professional skills in a way that was interesting, engaging, and meaningful. I want to take it again and again!!
Extensive overview of the history and current status of water resource topics and challenges.
I got an introductory understanding of many key water related issues across sectors.
Very valuable knowledge on water resources

I learned about a variety of different aspects of water management, from the more technical and scientific to the social and political. We explored several themes that framed the course, for example the hard vs soft path for water management. I also gained experience in writing a case study of a particular issue with constructive feedback from the professor.

I gained a broader knowledge of water management issues, adding to my relatively narrow expertise. I appreciated learning about a variety of solutions that can be applied to different problems in different ways, with the understanding that the same solution will not work every time.
Water resource management, water quality, water use and allocation policy
I gained a comprehensive view of water management across a variety of domestic and international contexts.

This course approached water issues from a wide variety of perspectives and lenses, most of which I hadn't previously considered. I feel like I can go into the world and work with water with a much deeper understanding of the complexities surrounding water and society.

A great overview of different aspects of water resources management. I'm confident that I'm now competent in learning additional knowledge and skills on the job around any of the topics covered in this course.

The seminar-style in which this course was designed and carried out, helped me draw from previous courses and professional experience to provide solutions to real-world problems. I really enjoyed the case studies presented in class -from U.S. and also from other countries around the world- as well as Shimi's extraordinary guidance and passion for the subject of water management. 
This course gave me a perfect balance of social and scientific tools to better manage water in times of scarcity, as well as in times in abundance and even in conflict. 
By looking at current U.S. water-related laws and several international projects concerning water management made me realize the importance of working collaboratively to understand and then to propose solutions. A very clear takeaway from this course is the need to implement several methodologies and techniques to cope with the seasonality and variability of water, especially in the era of climate change.

My expectations were far exceeded, particularly the expectations I had for the project/paper portion of the course, which I gained much more from than I anticipated. Synthesizing the multi-faceted topic from the many angles we were introduced to through the class and conducting research that included engaging with relevant stakeholders was rewarding and demonstrated that gaining expertise and playing an important role is these types of issues is rewarding and purposeful.
Very well
Very highly - I wanted to learn more about industry related water stresses and learned a lot about a whole range of issues.
They aligned with my expectations
This course exceeded my expectations.
It aligned well with my expectations.
Very well.
This course was fantastic in its presentation of opportunities for group work and interaction with a diverse range of water managers and professionals.
Very well. Shimi outlines things very clearly to give accurate expectations and clear ideas of what the class will include.
As someone trained in natural science, this course opened a door for me to explore management and policy.

The fact that this course is considered a middle-level applied course, really fulfilled my expectations, due to the content related to present and actual problems in the world of water. 
With the help of the Teacher assistant and with Shimi's guidance on the final paper, the class learning were robust and very comprehensive, starting from a very theoretical background of water measurement to specific examples were management of water has been successful, and those that failed.
Strengths are the instructor, the interdisciplinary material, the small size, and the engaging and dynamic teaching and learning strategies.
I think the course is very well done. Shimi has clearly put a lot of thought into crafting each topic area.

I loved how the class was separated into topic area, so that each seminar could focus in depth on specific issues. It was engaging and called for participation, so I got to learn a lot from my classmates as well. The schedule made the class feel a bit choppy at times because we missed a number of classes for spring break, and some unexpected reasons (illness, travel, school-wide events). Since it is likely moving to a twice a week class, it will be easier to form a sense of continuity. Also, with shorter class sessions, perhaps watching the films on your own time and devoting the class schedule to discussion/lecturing would be better.
Good class overall

The course is very well structured. The quizzes and homework assignments reinforce material in a helpful way and the case study project enables students to delve deeper into the content as it relates to a specific location. I really liked the guest lectures, especially for the Indian water settlements and WASH classes. The field trips are also great. The only suggestion I have for improving the course is to provide clearer guidance on what students should include or focus on in the reading responses.
I appreciated the clear division of topic by week; I would have liked to see some more non-local examples in the water quality discussions.
Worth the work, learnt a lot!

Strengths: The field trips, visiting lecturers, and group discussions.

Weaknesses: The course meeting time was entirely too long and should be split between two days. I became disengaged after 2 hours in class, and often struggled through the last hour.

The only weakness of this course is also its strength--the lectures, field trips, and other content are all great, but there's isn't enough time to cover everything in the depth it deserves, even with nearly 4 hours of class per week. Shimi is a great lecturer and very receptive to answering student questions and fostering discussion...but there just wasn't enough time to discuss everything! With the format changing to 3 credits for next year, is it possble to turn this into 2 semesters of 3 credit classes?

Strength: 1. Shimi's lectures are very clear and well-structured. 2. The field trips were great learning experiences.
Weakness: writing the term paper with a partner who didn't seem to care as much about the topic as I did was very difficult.

Although I was aware from the beginning that the content had mostly domestic examples -from the U.S.- , I would recommend to enrich its content by the additions of previous-years student projects into the curriculum of the course

A definitive strength of this class is the wide-range of educational tools that it provides, ranging from field visits, to readings, discussions, formal presentation of a topic and the delivery of a high-quality final paper.
If the syllabus excites you, take this class. Give it your all and come prepared to engage during class time; you will learn more than you expect.
If you are interested in water resources, definitely take this class.

This is by far the best class that I've taken at FES. I would recommend it to anyone who even has a slight interest in water. Even if you don't think that you're interested in water issues, you should take this class.
It covers management aspects of water as opposed to the science of water

This is a great class with one of the best teachers at FES! Anyone interested in water, agriculture, energy, climate change, indigenous rights, and/or urban planning should definitely take this class. It will challenge you to explore complex issues with a critical lens and open mind.
If you're interested in water, a definite must!
If you want to work on water quality issues or even land management, you need this course!!
Select a research topic that you have professional interest in - this will support your engagement with the final research paper.

If you plan to work with water at any point in your career, take this class. It will introduce you to the concepts you need to learn in an incredibly engaging way. Do the readings, think critically and ask questions.

1. Be willing to commit sufficient time outside the classroom to work, read, and write.
2. Coordinate well with your paper writing partner.

Since it is a 4-credit course it involves a lot of work. Do not take this class along with other high-reading-demanding classes and/or other 4-credit courses. On the other hand, the discussions are very rich, and depending on the level of engagement of other students, the weekly discussions and final project can provide an invaluable insight to water management around the world.
